snippet: Contagion depends on a complex interplay between a virus and its victim, including where it enters the body, the types of cells in which it can reproduce and whether it can then escape.
abstract: Scientific opinion varies widely concerning dangers posed by a study in which avian influenza virus was genetically modified in order to make it more contagious; though unmodified virus has only infected 600 people since its discovery, unusually high mortality rate gives it the potential to eventually mutate into an unprecedented pandemic, alarming those concerned about what terrorists could do with the information.

byline.original: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and DENISE GRADY

lead_paragraph: Contagion depends on a complex interplay between a virus and its victim, including where it enters the body, the types of cells in which it can reproduce and whether it can then escape.

headline.seo: An Explanation of How Avian Flu Spreads
headline.main: How Hard Would It Be for Avian Flu to Spread?
headline.print_headline: How Hard Would It Be For Avian Flu To Spread?
